trans-unit.source: Certificates and Keys
trans-unit.target: Certificates and Keys

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: Certificates and Keys
trans-unit.target: Certificates and Keys

trans-unit.source: <token>firstref_acs</token> offers two different ways to sign and encrypt tokens: X.509 certificates with a private key and 256-bit symmetric keys.
trans-unit.target: <token>firstref_acs</token> offers two different ways to sign and encrypt tokens: X.509 certificates with a private key and 256-bit symmetric keys.

trans-unit.source: You can configure each certificate or key to sign tokens for particular relying party applications or for all relying party applications in the namespace, and you designate certificates and keys to be primary or secondary.
trans-unit.target: You can configure each certificate or key to sign tokens for particular relying party applications or for all relying party applications in the namespace, and you designate certificates and keys to be primary or secondary.

trans-unit.source: To add and configure token signing, encryption, and decryption certificates and keys, use the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service or the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: To add and configure token signing, encryption, and decryption certificates and keys, use the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Service or the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Signing Tokens
trans-unit.target: Signing Tokens

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> signs all security tokens it issues with an X.509 certificate (with a private key) or a 256-bit symmetric key.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> signs all security tokens it issues with an X.509 certificate (with a private key) or a 256-bit symmetric key.

trans-unit.source: Your choice of a signing credential type (certificate or key) depends on the token format that you select for your <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens.
trans-unit.target: Your choice of a signing credential type (certificate or key) depends on the token format that you select for your <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see “Token signing” in <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see “Token signing” in <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>.

trans-unit.source: When selecting what type of signing credential to create, consider the following:
trans-unit.target: When selecting what type of signing credential to create, consider the following:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>SAML tokens</embeddedLabel> are signed with X.509 certificates.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>SAML tokens</embeddedLabel> are signed with X.509 certificates.

trans-unit.source: SAML is the default token format used by applications built on the Windows Identity Foundation (WIF).
trans-unit.target: SAML is the default token format used by applications built on the Windows Identity Foundation (WIF).

trans-unit.source: SAML tokens can be issued over multiple protocols, such as WS-Federation and WS-Trust.
trans-unit.target: SAML tokens can be issued over multiple protocols, such as WS-Federation and WS-Trust.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>SWT tokens</embeddedLabel> are signed with 256-bit symmetric keys.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>SWT tokens</embeddedLabel> are signed with 256-bit symmetric keys.

trans-unit.source: SWT tokens can be issued over multiple protocols, such as OAuth WRAP and WS-Federation.
trans-unit.target: SWT tokens can be issued over multiple protocols, such as OAuth WRAP and WS-Federation.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>JWT tokens</embeddedLabel> can be signed by X.509 certificates or 256-bit symmetric keys.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>JWT tokens</embeddedLabel> can be signed by X.509 certificates or 256-bit symmetric keys.

trans-unit.source: JWT tokens can be issued over multiple protocols, such as WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth 2.0.
trans-unit.target: JWT tokens can be issued over multiple protocols, such as WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth 2.0.

trans-unit.source: Namespace or dedicated certificates and keys
trans-unit.target: Namespace or dedicated certificates and keys

trans-unit.source: You can configure a signing certificate or a symmetric key so it is used for the entire <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> or only for a particular relying party application in the namespace.
trans-unit.target: You can configure a signing certificate or a symmetric key so it is used for the entire <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> or only for a particular relying party application in the namespace.

trans-unit.source: The difference is as follows:
trans-unit.target: The difference is as follows:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel><token>ad_acs_namespace</token></embeddedLabel>—When a signing certificate or key is configured for the entire <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the certificate or key to sign tokens for all relying party applications in this namespace that do not have an application-specific certificate or key.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel><token>ad_acs_namespace</token></embeddedLabel>—When a signing certificate or key is configured for the entire <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the certificate or key to sign tokens for all relying party applications in this namespace that do not have an application-specific certificate or key.

trans-unit.source: A namespace-scoped certificate is also used to sign <token>secondref_acs</token> WS-Federation metadata.
trans-unit.target: A namespace-scoped certificate is also used to sign <token>secondref_acs</token> WS-Federation metadata.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Dedicated</embeddedLabel>—If you configure a signing certificate or key to be used for a particular relying party application, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the signing certificate or key only to sign tokens delivered to the specified relying party application.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Dedicated</embeddedLabel>—If you configure a signing certificate or key to be used for a particular relying party application, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the signing certificate or key only to sign tokens delivered to the specified relying party application.

trans-unit.source: If you create or enter a dedicated symmetric key, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the dedicated key to sign tokens for the application.
trans-unit.target: If you create or enter a dedicated symmetric key, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the dedicated key to sign tokens for the application.

trans-unit.source: If the dedicated key expires and is not replaced, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the symmetric key for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> to sign tokens for the application.
trans-unit.target: If the dedicated key expires and is not replaced, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the symmetric key for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> to sign tokens for the application.

trans-unit.source: As a security best-practice, when using symmetric keys, create a dedicated key for each relying party application.
trans-unit.target: As a security best-practice, when using symmetric keys, create a dedicated key for each relying party application.

trans-unit.source: An X.509 certificate can safely be shared by multiple applications in an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: An X.509 certificate can safely be shared by multiple applications in an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: When you add a Microsoft-managed relying party application to a managed namespace, such as adding a Service Bus relying party application to a Service Bus namespace, do not use application-specific (dedicated) certificates or keys.
trans-unit.target: When you add a Microsoft-managed relying party application to a managed namespace, such as adding a Service Bus relying party application to a Service Bus namespace, do not use application-specific (dedicated) certificates or keys.

trans-unit.source: Instead, select the ACS option to use the certificates and keys that are configured for all applications in the managed namespace.
trans-unit.target: Instead, select the ACS option to use the certificates and keys that are configured for all applications in the managed namespace.

trans-unit.source: For all other relying party applications, use application-specific certificates and keys.
trans-unit.target: For all other relying party applications, use application-specific certificates and keys.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="3ad43749-6e00-4126-ad87-46a85a9e8f24" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Managed Namespaces</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="3ad43749-6e00-4126-ad87-46a85a9e8f24" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Managed Namespaces</link>.

trans-unit.source: When you configure a relying party application that uses the X.509 certificate for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> to sign JWT tokens, links to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> certificate and the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> key appear on the page for the relying party application in the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: When you configure a relying party application that uses the X.509 certificate for the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> to sign JWT tokens, links to the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> certificate and the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> key appear on the page for the relying party application in the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: However, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses only the namespace certificate to sign tokens for the relying party application.
trans-unit.target: However, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses only the namespace certificate to sign tokens for the relying party application.

trans-unit.source: Signing certificates are typically used to sign tokens for all relying party applications in a namespace.
trans-unit.target: Signing certificates are typically used to sign tokens for all relying party applications in a namespace.

trans-unit.source: The public key component of a namespace signing certificate is published in the <token>secondref_acs</token> WS-Federation metadata, which enables relying party applications to automate their configuration.
trans-unit.target: The public key component of a namespace signing certificate is published in the <token>secondref_acs</token> WS-Federation metadata, which enables relying party applications to automate their configuration.

trans-unit.source: The public keys of certificates that are assigned only to a particular relying party application are not present in the <token>secondref_acs</token> WS-Federation metadata and are used only when independent control over a relying party application’s signing certificate is required.
trans-unit.target: The public keys of certificates that are assigned only to a particular relying party application are not present in the <token>secondref_acs</token> WS-Federation metadata and are used only when independent control over a relying party application’s signing certificate is required.

trans-unit.source: Primary certificates and keys
trans-unit.target: Primary certificates and keys

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can maintain several certificates and keys, but use only designated certificates and keys to sign tokens.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can maintain several certificates and keys, but use only designated certificates and keys to sign tokens.

trans-unit.source: The certificates and keys designated for signing are known as <newTerm>primary</newTerm> certificates and keys.
trans-unit.target: The certificates and keys designated for signing are known as <newTerm>primary</newTerm> certificates and keys.

trans-unit.source: To designate a certificate or key as primary, select the <ui>Make primary</ui> item on the page for the certificate or key.
trans-unit.target: To designate a certificate or key as primary, select the <ui>Make primary</ui> item on the page for the certificate or key.

trans-unit.source: To designate a different certificate as primary, select the <ui>Make primary</ui> item on the page for the other certificate or key.
trans-unit.target: To designate a different certificate as primary, select the <ui>Make primary</ui> item on the page for the other certificate or key.

trans-unit.source: When you do, <token>secondref_acs</token> automatically demotes any existing primary certificates or keys to non-primary.
trans-unit.target: When you do, <token>secondref_acs</token> automatically demotes any existing primary certificates or keys to non-primary.

trans-unit.source: When at least one certificate or key is primary, non-primary certificates and keys are not used for signing until they are promoted to a primary status by the administrator, even if the primary certificate or key is invalid or is expired.
trans-unit.target: When at least one certificate or key is primary, non-primary certificates and keys are not used for signing until they are promoted to a primary status by the administrator, even if the primary certificate or key is invalid or is expired.

trans-unit.source: However, if none of the certificates (or keys) is primary, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the non-primary certificate that has the earliest valid start date.
trans-unit.target: However, if none of the certificates (or keys) is primary, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses the non-primary certificate that has the earliest valid start date.

trans-unit.source: The public key component of both primary and non-primary certificates is published in the <token>secondref_acs</token> WS-Federation metadata to enable programmatic certificate rollover.
trans-unit.target: The public key component of both primary and non-primary certificates is published in the <token>secondref_acs</token> WS-Federation metadata to enable programmatic certificate rollover.

trans-unit.source: However <token>secondref_acs</token> only uses primary certificates and keys to sign tokens.
trans-unit.target: However <token>secondref_acs</token> only uses primary certificates and keys to sign tokens.

trans-unit.source: Effective and expiration dates of signing keys
trans-unit.target: Effective and expiration dates of signing keys

trans-unit.source: When you add 256-bit symmetric signing keys, you must also specify an effective date and an expiration date.
trans-unit.target: When you add 256-bit symmetric signing keys, you must also specify an effective date and an expiration date.

trans-unit.source: The effective date indicates the date that this key takes effect.
trans-unit.target: The effective date indicates the date that this key takes effect.

trans-unit.source: The expiration date indicates the date that this key expires and cannot be used to sign tokens.
trans-unit.target: The expiration date indicates the date that this key expires and cannot be used to sign tokens.

trans-unit.source: Encrypting Tokens
trans-unit.target: Encrypting Tokens

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can elect to encrypt any SAML 1.1 or SAML 2.0 token that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues to your relying party applications.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, you can elect to encrypt any SAML 1.1 or SAML 2.0 token that <token>secondref_acs</token> issues to your relying party applications.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> does not support encryption of SWT or JWT tokens.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> does not support encryption of SWT or JWT tokens.

trans-unit.source: Token encryption is required for web services that use proof-of-possession tokens over the WS-Trust protocol.
trans-unit.target: Token encryption is required for web services that use proof-of-possession tokens over the WS-Trust protocol.

trans-unit.source: If you use <token>secondref_acs</token> to manage authentication for such a relying party application, all <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens for this relying party application must be encrypted.
trans-unit.target: If you use <token>secondref_acs</token> to manage authentication for such a relying party application, all <token>secondref_acs</token>-issued tokens for this relying party application must be encrypted.

trans-unit.source: In all other scenarios, token encryption is optional.
trans-unit.target: In all other scenarios, token encryption is optional.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> encrypts SAML tokens by using an X.509 certificate containing a public key (.cer file).
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> encrypts SAML tokens by using an X.509 certificate containing a public key (.cer file).

trans-unit.source: The relying party application token decrypts the token by a using a private key for that X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: The relying party application token decrypts the token by a using a private key for that X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see “Token encryption” in <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see “Token encryption” in <link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>.

trans-unit.source: Decrypting tokens
trans-unit.target: Decrypting tokens

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> can accept encrypted tokens from WS-Federation identity providers, such as <token>secondref_adfs2</token>.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> can accept encrypted tokens from WS-Federation identity providers, such as <token>secondref_adfs2</token>.

trans-unit.source: The WS-Federation identity provider receives the public key of an X.509 certificate when it imports WS-Federation metadata from <token>secondref_acs</token> and it uses this public key to encrypt the security token that is forwarded to <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: The WS-Federation identity provider receives the public key of an X.509 certificate when it imports WS-Federation metadata from <token>secondref_acs</token> and it uses this public key to encrypt the security token that is forwarded to <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> decrypts the token by using the private key of this X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> decrypts the token by using the private key of this X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="dbc91fd8-672a-4eb9-941a-1d6a2beaa615" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How To: Configure ADFS 2.0 as an Identity Provider</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="dbc91fd8-672a-4eb9-941a-1d6a2beaa615" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How To: Configure ADFS 2.0 as an Identity Provider</link>.

trans-unit.source: Primary token decryption certificates
trans-unit.target: Primary token decryption certificates

trans-unit.source: You can maintain multiple token decryption certificates for a relying party application or <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: You can maintain multiple token decryption certificates for a relying party application or <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: When you designate a certificate as <newTerm>primary</newTerm>, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses that certificate to decrypt the tokens from WS-Federation identity providers, and uses non-primary certificates only if the attempt to use the primary certificate fails.
trans-unit.target: When you designate a certificate as <newTerm>primary</newTerm>, <token>secondref_acs</token> uses that certificate to decrypt the tokens from WS-Federation identity providers, and uses non-primary certificates only if the attempt to use the primary certificate fails.

trans-unit.source: To designate a decryption certificate as primary, select the <ui>Make primary</ui> item on the page for the certificate.
trans-unit.target: To designate a decryption certificate as primary, select the <ui>Make primary</ui> item on the page for the certificate.

trans-unit.source: To designate a different certificate as primary, select the <ui>Make primary</ui> item on the page for the other certificate.
trans-unit.target: To designate a different certificate as primary, select the <ui>Make primary</ui> item on the page for the other certificate.

trans-unit.source: When you do, <token>secondref_acs</token> automatically demotes any existing primary decryption certificates to non-primary.
trans-unit.target: When you do, <token>secondref_acs</token> automatically demotes any existing primary decryption certificates to non-primary.

trans-unit.source: ACS Limitations for X.509 Certificate Files
trans-unit.target: ACS Limitations for X.509 Certificate Files

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, X.509 certificates that contain only a public key (.cer file) can be used when creating a service identity, validating a signature of an identity provider, or encrypting SAML tokens.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, X.509 certificates that contain only a public key (.cer file) can be used when creating a service identity, validating a signature of an identity provider, or encrypting SAML tokens.

trans-unit.source: X.509 certificate files that contain only a public key (.cer file) must be DER-encoded to be used with <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: X.509 certificate files that contain only a public key (.cer file) must be DER-encoded to be used with <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Base64-encoded certificate files are currently not supported.
trans-unit.target: Base64-encoded certificate files are currently not supported.

trans-unit.source: Uploading a base64-encoded certificate to <token>secondref_acs</token> will result in a validation error when <token>secondref_acs</token> receives an incoming token that requires that certificate.
trans-unit.target: Uploading a base64-encoded certificate to <token>secondref_acs</token> will result in a validation error when <token>secondref_acs</token> receives an incoming token that requires that certificate.

trans-unit.source: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, X.509 certificates must either be self-signed, or signed and chained directly to a public certification authority.
trans-unit.target: In <token>secondref_acs</token>, X.509 certificates must either be self-signed, or signed and chained directly to a public certification authority.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> will not work with certificates that are issued by a private certification authority.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> will not work with certificates that are issued by a private certification authority.

trans-unit.source: X.509 ceritificates imported into <token>secondref_acs</token> must not be expired.
trans-unit.target: X.509 ceritificates imported into <token>secondref_acs</token> must not be expired.

trans-unit.source: Obtaining an X.509 Certificate
trans-unit.target: Obtaining an X.509 Certificate

trans-unit.source: There are several ways to obtain an X.509 certificate for token signing, token encryption, or decryption.
trans-unit.target: There are several ways to obtain an X.509 certificate for token signing, token encryption, or decryption.

trans-unit.source: The method that you use depends on your requirements and the tools available in your organization.
trans-unit.target: The method that you use depends on your requirements and the tools available in your organization.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Commercial Certification Authority</embeddedLabel>—You can purchase an X.509 certificate from a commercial certification authority.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Commercial Certification Authority</embeddedLabel>—You can purchase an X.509 certificate from a commercial certification authority.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Generate a Self-Signed Certificate</embeddedLabel>—You can generate your own self-signed certificate to use with <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Generate a Self-Signed Certificate</embeddedLabel>—You can generate your own self-signed certificate to use with <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: If you are running a Windows-based operating system, you can use MakeCert.exe, a tool included in the <externalLink><linkText>Microsoft Windows Software Development Kit</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=214104</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=214104) to generate a self-signed certificate.
trans-unit.target: If you are running a Windows-based operating system, you can use MakeCert.exe, a tool included in the <externalLink><linkText>Microsoft Windows Software Development Kit</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=214104</linkUri></externalLink> (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=214104) to generate a self-signed certificate.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command generates a self-signed certificate in your personal certificate store.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command generates a self-signed certificate in your personal certificate store.

trans-unit.source: where <service_namespace_name> is the name of your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: where <service_namespace_name> is the name of your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: You can then export the private key from your personal store as a .pfx file and use the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal to upload it to <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: You can then export the private key from your personal store as a .pfx file and use the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal to upload it to <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Exporting a Self-Signed Certificate
trans-unit.target: Exporting a Self-Signed Certificate

trans-unit.source: These instructions explain how to export a self-signed certification from a computer running <token>win8_client_2</token>, <token>win8_server_2</token>, <token>win7_client_secondref</token>, or <token>windowsver</token>.
trans-unit.target: These instructions explain how to export a self-signed certification from a computer running <token>win8_client_2</token>, <token>win8_server_2</token>, <token>win7_client_secondref</token>, or <token>windowsver</token>.

trans-unit.source: To export your self-signed certificate
trans-unit.target: To export your self-signed certificate

trans-unit.source: Start MMC.exe and add the <system>Certificates</system> snap-in to your MMC console.
trans-unit.target: Start MMC.exe and add the <system>Certificates</system> snap-in to your MMC console.

trans-unit.source: Double-click <ui>Certificates - Current User</ui>, <ui>Personal</ui>, and then <ui>Certificates</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Double-click <ui>Certificates - Current User</ui>, <ui>Personal</ui>, and then <ui>Certificates</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Right-click a certificate, click <ui>All Tasks</ui>, and then click <ui>Export</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Right-click a certificate, click <ui>All Tasks</ui>, and then click <ui>Export</ui>.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Certificate Export Wizard Welcome</ui> page, click <ui>Next</ui>.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Certificate Export Wizard Welcome</ui> page, click <ui>Next</ui>.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Export Private Key</ui> page, select <ui>Yes, export the private key</ui>, and then click <ui>Next</ui>.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Export Private Key</ui> page, select <ui>Yes, export the private key</ui>, and then click <ui>Next</ui>.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Export File Format</ui> page, click <ui>Personal Information Exchange - PKCS #12 (.PFX)</ui>.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Export File Format</ui> page, click <ui>Personal Information Exchange - PKCS #12 (.PFX)</ui>.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>Password</ui> fields, enter a password and confirmation password, and then click <ui>Next</ui>.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>Password</ui> fields, enter a password and confirmation password, and then click <ui>Next</ui>.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>File name</ui> field, enter a path and file name with a .pfx file name extension, and then click <ui>Next</ui>.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>File name</ui> field, enter a path and file name with a .pfx file name extension, and then click <ui>Next</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Finish</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Finish</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Valid Dates of Certificates and Keys
trans-unit.target: Valid Dates of Certificates and Keys

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> evaluates the start and end dates (and date-times) of certificates and keys in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> evaluates the start and end dates (and date-times) of certificates and keys in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

trans-unit.source: As a result, <token>secondref_acs</token> might consider keys and certificates to be invalid even when they are valid in the local time of the local computer or in another time zone.
trans-unit.target: As a result, <token>secondref_acs</token> might consider keys and certificates to be invalid even when they are valid in the local time of the local computer or in another time zone.

trans-unit.source: To ensure that the certificate or key is valid immediately, adjust the dates to UTC time.
trans-unit.target: To ensure that the certificate or key is valid immediately, adjust the dates to UTC time.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, <token>secondref_acs</token> might fail to issue a token because the key or certificate is not yet valid.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, <token>secondref_acs</token> might fail to issue a token because the key or certificate is not yet valid.
